newsitem.title: USA: Stephanopoulos does not rule out politics.
newsitem.headline: Stephanopoulos does not rule out politics.

text.p: White House adviser George Stephanopoulos, who is leaving the Clinton administration for a university teaching job, said on Wednesday he may run for political office some day.

"It's something I want to think about," he told a news conference at Columbia University, where he will teach political science next year. Asked if he had political aspirations, he said, "I certainly haven't ruled it out."
In addition to teaching, Stephanopoulos, 35, said he planned to work in television and write a book after he leaves his White House job.

At Columbia, where he earned an undergraduate degree in political science in 1982, he will be a visiting professor for two years, teaching seminars, delivering lectures and holding informal "town meetings" with students. He will focus on politics, policy, the press and the presidency, he said.

After helping in President Bill Clinton's 1992 campaign, Stephanopoulos became White House communications director and briefly served as the president's spokesman. As senior adviser behind the scenes, he has been a Clinton confidant and worked closely with members of Congress.
Stephanopoulos' boyish good looks also made him a bit of a celebrity. Asked by a reporter how he felt about becoming one of New York City's most eligible bachelors, he laughed and refused to comment.
